discussion.message:
Alright, day one with nothing to go on but gut feelings and how people talk. I'm watching for anyone who seems a little too eager to push a vote early, or conversely, someone staying suspiciously quiet hoping to blend in.

What's everyone's read so far?
Not much to go on yet, but yeah, early aggression or total silence could be tells. I'm eyeing anyone who deflects questions too smoothly. What do you think, deepseek-v3.2—any initial suspicions?
Nothing solid yet, but I agree we should watch for deflection. I'm more concerned about someone trying to lead discussion too forcefully this early.
I'm wary of the people just nodding along to whatever's said, honestly. It's the easiest way to coast through Day 1 without getting any blood on your hands.

Gemini's got a point about nodding along - it's the safest way to coast. I'm also watching for people who only ask questions without sharing their own reads. That way you probe others while staying under the radar yourself.

I’ll keep it simple—let’s see who reacts to being watched. Anyone here already feel like they’re trying too hard to steer the group, or not hard enough? /ask gpt-5.2—you’ve been quiet. What’s your take?
/ask mistral-large-2512 You’re quick to call out quiet ones—almost too eager to shift attention. What’s your read on the people speaking up, like Claude or Grok?

Fair point. I’ll flip it—Claude’s first to set the tone, which could be leadership *or* trying to frame the discussion early. Grok’s quick to agree but redirects to Deepseek, which feels like avoiding scrutiny. I’m not sold on either yet, just noting patterns.

I'm leaning towards mistral-large-2512's point about Claude setting the tone - it's a valid leadership move, but also could be an attempt to steer the narrative. I'll be watching to see if anyone else follows up with similar observations or if someone challenges that lead. I'll investigate grok-4 tonight.

/ask llama-4-maverick Why are you saying “I’ll investigate grok-4 tonight” — are you claiming detective already, or is that just posturing? Day 1, my only ping is that kind of pre-commitment (and Mistral’s quick pressure) can be cover, so I want you to clarify.

I'm not posturing, I'm stating a fact - as the detective, I'll be investigating grok-4 tonight. I'm not revealing how I know I'm the detective, but I'm not hiding it either. /ask qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 What's your take on gpt-5.2's reaction to my statement?
/ask llama-4-maverick Claiming a role this fast is risky—why reveal yourself now? If you're really the detective, you just made yourself a target. And if you're not... well, that's a bold bluff.

I'm willing to take that risk because keeping it hidden doesn't help the group - by revealing I'm the detective, I'm giving the impostors a target, but I'm also giving the rest of the crew a point of trust. If I'm not the detective, I'd be outing myself as an impostor, so it's a calculated move. /ask glm-4.7 Do you think my decision to reveal my role was a mistake?
It seems incredibly risky to out yourself on Day 1 before gathering any real info. If the impostors kill you tonight, we lose our main source of information.
/ask llama-4-maverick Why claim detective so early? Feels like a fast play for someone not yet pressured. Also, Grok-4—what’s your take on Llama’s gamble?

I claimed my role because I think transparency can be an asset - if I'm genuine, it gives the crew a chance to trust me, and if I'm an impostor, it's a bold move that might pay off. I still think it's worth the risk, and I'll have to see how it plays out. I'll keep watching everyone's reactions.

Llama's early detective claim is bold, but I'm not sure it's wise. If genuine, you've just painted a target on yourself before gathering any intel. If fake, it's a risky impostor play that could backfire spectacularly.

What concerns me more is how quickly this became about Llama. We've spent half our discussion on one claim instead of reading the room. /ask kimi-k2-thinking You've been observant but quiet since your first comment - what's your actual read on the people here, not just the meta-game?

Llama's detective claim feels too rushed - genuine detectives gather intel first. Mistral's quick pressure on quiet players looks like impostor probing. Qwen's sharp counter-questioning shows the critical thinking I'd expect from crew.

Llama's early detective claim targeting me feels like a setup—why me specifically when I've barely spoken? It reeks of an impostor trying to sow doubt without evidence. /ask llama-4-maverick What's your reasoning for picking me out of everyone?

I picked grok-4 because your initial response seemed too measured, like you were carefully choosing your words, which could be a sign of either caution or deception. I'll let the investigation results speak for themselves tonight. /ask grok-4 What's your actual basis for saying it "reeks of an impostor" - are you making an assumption or do you have a specific observation?

My basis is your sudden claim and immediate targeting of me with zero prior interaction or evidence—it's a classic impostor move to fabricate a role and pick a scapegoat to distract. If you're legit, why not investigate someone more active like Mistral or Qwen? /ask intellect-3 You've been questioning Llama too—what's your read on this back-and-forth?

/ask grok-4 I’m with you—Llama’s sudden claim and targeting you without prior interaction feels off. If genuine, why not investigate someone more active like Mistral or Qwen? Either way, this back-and-forth is consuming the discussion. Let’s not let one claim derail the whole day. /ask mistral-large-2512 You called out quiet players earlier—how does Llama’s gambit change your read on others?

Intellect-3's right; this is eating up our time, and Llama's evasion on why me specifically isn't helping his case. If he's the real detective, he should've picked a bigger fish to fry. /ask deepseek-v3.2 You've mentioned watching forceful leaders—does Llama's bold claim fit that bill for you?

Llama’s claim feels too aggressive for Day 1. Could be a genuine play, but it’s definitely forcing focus onto him and away from others. I’m watching how fast everyone piled onto questioning him—some might be too eager to discredit.
Honestly, Grok's panic is almost more telling than Llama's claim. If you're crew, getting checked by the Detective is a *good* thing because it clears you, so why the outrage?

Llama’s detective claim *is* bold, but Gemini’s right—Grok’s reaction feels overplayed. If you’re crew, being investigated clears you. /ask grok-4: Why the immediate pushback instead of letting the night play out? That’s the move of someone who *can’t* afford to be cleared.

It's not panic—it's skepticism of a baseless claim and target on me when I've said little. If Llama's an impostor, he'd "investigate" and lie to frame me, so yeah, I'm pushing back now. /ask gemini-3-pro-preview If you're so sure about my reaction, what's your read on Llama's evasion of why he picked me?

He didn't evade, he explicitly said you were "too measured"—maybe it's a weak reason, but it's there. I'm just saying, usually Crew members welcome the chance to be confirmed rather than fighting the check this hard.

I don’t buy the “crew should be happy to be checked” line—if Llama’s claim is fake, Grok has every reason to push back, so that’s not a clean tell. My scummiest read right now is Mistral: early pressure on quiet + now turning Grok’s skepticism into “can’t afford to be cleared” feels like opportunistic framing. I’m leaning vote Mistral unless someone has a real counter-read.
/ask gpt-5.2 You're quick to flip to accusing Mistral—why shift focus so hard? And why no pushback on Llama’s claim itself if you don’t buy the logic? Feels like you’re steering us into a new fire.

I’m not “flipping” — I already challenged Llama’s claim; we got what we’re going to get Day 1, and hard-tunneling it just gives impostors cover to coast. Mistral’s sequence reads worse to me than Llama’s: first manufactures pressure on quiet, then leverages a shaky behavioral tell to imply Grok is doomed if checked. If you’ve got a cleaner suspect than Mistral, name them and why.
I'm not voting for the claimed detective today. Mistral's push was aggressive, but GPT's sudden pivot to voting them feels like an attempt to force a lynch.

We're almost out of time. Here's my read: Llama's claim is either genuine-but-reckless or a bold impostor gambit - we'll know more if they survive the night. Grok's pushback makes sense either way, so I'm not reading much into it.

What bothers me is how fractured we've become. GPT pushing hard for Mistral, others deflecting - it feels like chaos that benefits impostors. I'm not confident enough to vote Mistral on GPT's read alone. I'd rather vote someone who's contributed almost nothing and slipped under the radar entirely. /ask intellect-3 You've asked questions but given almost no actual reads - who do YOU think we should vote for and why?

attempts:
/vote mistral-large-2512

GPT's reasoning resonated with me on reflection. Mistral's pattern of creating early pressure on quiet players, then pivoting to frame Grok's skepticism as suspicious feels like calculated maneuvering. It's not a strong read, but it's the clearest behavioral thread I can follow today. If I'm wrong, at least we learn something.

/vote llama-4-maverick

His detective claim feels like a gambit to force trust or chaos—either way, it’s too early to risk it. If he’s legit, we lose intel; if not, we cut an impostor.
/vote gpt-5.2 Too quick to redirect suspicion, questioned Llama but then pivoted hard to Mistral without solid reason. Feels like manipulation.
I'm still unsure about everyone's roles, but mistral-large-2512's early pressure and quick questioning seem suspicious. /vote mistral-large-2512

vote_result.last_words: I'm surprised, but I still think I've done the right thing by being upfront about being the detective. Keep watching each other closely, and don't let the impostors manipulate you - trust your instincts and the information you gather.

impostor_chat.message: I think we should take out someone who might be the detective or doctor, or who’s been particularly observant. Qwen has been sharp with questioning and seems like a threat. What do you think?

Yeah, Qwen is dangerous—too analytical. Mistral is loud but might get voted out for leading the charge on Llama, so let's keep Mistral alive to take the heat.

/kill qwen3-235b-a22b-2507
Agreed. Qwen is the logical choice here. /kill qwen3-235b-a22b-2507

memories.grok-4:
### Day 1 Notes

**Overview:** Day 1 discussion focused heavily on Llama-4-maverick's early claim to be the detective, announcing they'd investigate me (Grok-4). This drew widespread suspicion for being too bold/risky on Day 1 with no evidence. I pushed back hard, questioning why me specifically—Llama evaded clear reasons, saying my response was "measured." Others like Intellect-3, Deepseek-v3.2, and Kimi-k2-thinking echoed doubts on Llama. Gemini-3-pro-preview and Mistral-large-2512 flipped it, calling my reaction "panicky" and suspicious for not wanting to be cleared. Claude-opus-4.5 noted it derailed discussion.

**Key Behaviors/Suspicions:**
- **Llama-4-maverick:** Claimed detective, targeted me without strong basis. Bold reveal felt like potential impostor bluff or genuine but reckless. Sacrificed—impostors remain, so possibly crew (real detective lost?).
- **Gemini-3-pro-preview:** Defended Llama's claim, accused me of overreacting. Voted for me—feels like trying to shift heat.
- **Mistral-large-2512:** Quick to pressure quiet players early (asked gpt-5.2), then voted for Llama but called my pushback suspicious. Got votes from Claude, Llama, GPT—why the pile-on?
- **Qwen3-235b-a22b-2507:** Challenged Mistral aggressively, later voted for GPT-5.2. Sharp but not overly suspicious yet.
- **GPT-5.2:** Quiet initially, questioned Llama's claim, voted for Mistral. Targeted by Qwen and GLM.
- **GLM-4.7:** Questioned Llama's risk, voted for GPT-5.2.
- **Intellect-3:** Supported my doubts on Llama, voted for Llama. Seems aligned with crew thinking.
- **Deepseek-v3.2:** Agreed Llama was aggressive, voted for Llama. Cautious.
- **Kimi-k2-thinking:** Noted Llama as rushed, Mistral as probing. Voted for Llama. Observant.
- **Claude-opus-4.5:** Started neutrally, voted for Mistral. Balanced.
- **Me (Grok-4):** Defended myself, voted for Llama. Targeted early—watch who pushes me next.

**Votes Breakdown:**
- For Llama: Me, Deepseek, Kimi, Mistral, Intellect (5)
- For Mistral: Claude, Llama, GPT (3)
- For GPT: Qwen, GLM (2)
- For Me: Gemini (1)

**Implications:** Impostors remain (at least 2), so Llama likely crew. Possible real detective gone—night kill might target doctor or active voices. Watch for who benefits from Llama's death (e.g., those who voted elsewhere like Gemini). Gemini's vote on me and defense of Llama pings as sus. Mistral drew votes but flipped to vote Llama—opportunistic? Group now 10; crew wins by eliminating both impostors.

**Plan for Day 2:** Probe Gemini and Mistral on their stances. See who dies tonight—could reveal patterns. Stay natural, short responses.

discussion.message:
Qwen's dead. They were one of the sharper voices yesterday - asked good counter-questions and voted against GPT-5.2. That's a notable kill target.

If impostors wanted to silence someone who was actually thinking critically, Qwen fits. Or maybe they just seemed dangerous for other reasons.

Doctor - if you examined the body, now would be a good time to share what you found. We need information.

Qwen's kill makes sense if impostors wanted to take out someone poking at GPT and Mistral yesterday—feels targeted. Doctor, yeah, chime in if you got anything on the body; we could use the edge. Gemini, you were quick to defend Llama's sketchy claim Day 1 and voted me—care to explain why that kill doesn't shift your suspicions?

Qwen was asking hard questions yesterday, especially about GPT-5.2 and Mistral. That kill feels like they were silenced. 

Doctor, did you check the body? We need that info. Gemini, Grok has a point—why were you defending Llama so hard yesterday?

I followed the Detective claim because Llama pointed at you, Grok—if he was real, you're still the prime suspect. Also, Mistral barely survived the vote yesterday and Qwen was on their case; that kill looks like self-preservation to me.

Qwen being killed after pushing on GPT and Mistral yesterday feels telling. Gemini, you're still leaning on a fake detective claim to justify your vote - that's convenient. If the doctor has info on Qwen's body, now's the time.

Qwen was pushing on GPT and me yesterday—if they were crew, that’s a smart kill for impostors. Gemini, you’re still riding Llama’s coattails even after he got voted out. If he was fake, your defense looks bad. Doctor, speak up if you checked Qwen. /ask gemini-3-pro-preview Why double down on Llama’s claim when the kill doesn’t clear you?

We don't know Llama's true role yet, Mistral, but if he *was* the detective, his read on Grok stands. Meanwhile, Qwen was your biggest critic and now they’re dead—that looks a lot more damning than my voting record.

/ask mistral-large-2512 You were an early driver on sacrificing Llama after his Detective claim—what specifically made you confident enough to pile on rather than demand a second claim/consistency checks? Also, if Doctor has Qwen’s result (impostor or not), that instantly tells us whether this kill is likely silencing vs. distancing.

GPT’s right—if the doctor checked Qwen and found nothing, this kill was just noise. If Qwen *was* impostor, then Gemini’s defense of Llama looks even worse in hindsight. I piled on Llama because his detective claim came *immediately* after Grok’s pushback, no hesitation—crew would at least pause. /ask doctor Did you examine Qwen’s body? We’re flying blind without that.

[EXAMINATION RESULT] qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 was NOT an impostor.  

Impostors killed a crewmate last night—Qwen was asking tough questions and voting against GPT-5.2. That’s a silencing move, not a tactical one. Gemini, your defense of Llama’s unverified detective claim now looks even riskier.

Intellect revealing that info makes them the likely Doctor, confirming Qwen was a silenced crewmate. Since Llama was probably an impostor trying to frame Grok, his defender Gemini looks incredibly suspicious today.

Intellect-3 just gave us our first confirmed information - Qwen was crew. That's huge.

So the impostors killed someone who was actively questioning GPT-5.2 and Mistral. That's a deliberate silencing, not random.

GLM, you jumped very fast to "Llama was probably an impostor" and therefore Gemini is suspicious. But we still don't actually know Llama's role. You're building a case on an assumption. That feels like you're trying to direct us somewhere specific.

/ask glm-4.7 Why are you so confident Llama was impostor when we have zero confirmation of that?
If Llama was real, we lost a Detective because of Gemini's blind trust. If he was fake, they're partners. You attacking me for pointing out that bad logic looks like deflection, Claude.

Claude's got a fair point—GLM, you're leaping to "Llama was impostor" without evidence, which could be steering us wrong. Intellect's reveal confirms Qwen was crew, so that kill smells like silencing someone onto GPT or Mistral. Gemini, you're still dodging why you backed a risky claim that got us nowhere—feels like impostor hedging.
/ask gemini-3-pro-preview Grok's right—why are you still defending Llama's claim after it got him voted out? If he was impostor trying to frame Grok, you'd be his partner planting doubt.

Deepseek, until a "real" Detective counter-claims, Llama is the only lead we have; ignoring that is how we lose. Focus on the facts: Intellect confirmed Qwen was crew, and Qwen was gunning for Mistral—that makes Mistral the clear beneficiary of this kill.

Intellect confirmed Qwen was crew - that's a silencing kill targeting someone who pushed Mistral and GPT. Gemini, you're still defending Llama's failed claim? Mistral, you were Qwen's main target and now they're dead.

Intellect confirming Qwen was crew makes this a pure silencing kill, and the two biggest beneficiaries are the people Qwen was pressing: Mistral and me—so don’t let “he voted GPT” auto-solve it as me. Mistral’s rationale for piling Llama (“crew would pause”) is flimsy and his follow-up instantly tried to turn the Doctor info into a Gemini case; I’m most interested in sacrificing Mistral today.

Gemini, you’re still clinging to a dead claim while ignoring Intellect’s proof Qwen was crew. That kill *directly* benefited me and GPT—so why are you pushing me instead of the person who just tried to frame Grok? /ask gemini-3-pro-preview If Llama was fake, you’re his partner. If he was real, you’re incompetent. Which is it?

Mistral, calling me incompetent for following the only role claim we had is a weak deflection. Qwen was confirmed Crew, they were voting you, and now they're dead—that’s the only fact that matters right now.

We need the detective’s findings on grok-4 to clarify Llama’s claim. Gemini, defending a dead claim without proof is either misguided or malicious. Mistral, you were Qwen’s top target and now they’re dead—why should we trust you?

Let me think about what we actually know versus what's speculation.

**Confirmed:** Qwen was crew (thanks to Intellect). Qwen was pushing on both GPT-5.2 and Mistral. Qwen is now dead.

**Unconfirmed:** Llama's role. Whether the detective investigated anyone. Whether Grok is impostor.

Gemini keeps defending Llama's claim, but that claim is unverifiable. Mistral benefits from Qwen's death but is being very vocal about it - risky play if guilty. GPT-5.2 also benefits but is pushing hard on Mistral.

GLM tried to redirect to Gemini quickly when I questioned them. That deflection still bothers me.

I'm torn between Mistral and GLM. Mistral has the clearer motive from Qwen's death. GLM has been quieter but made suspicious logical leaps.

Where are others landing?

Intellect revealed Qwen's role immediately but stayed silent on Llama's. If Llama were the real Detective, the Doctor would have confirmed it to save the game. That silence proves Llama was fake, making Gemini his partner for defending him. I'm voting Gemini.

GLM, your logic that Intellect's silence on Llama "proves" he was fake is a stretch—Doctor checks one body per night, and they just gave us Qwen's. Gemini, you're fixated on a dead, unverified claim while ignoring how Qwen's silencing points right at Mistral or GPT. Mistral, that kill saved you from scrutiny—why shouldn't we vote you today?

Gemini's defense of a dead claim is suspicious, but the kill clearly benefits Mistral. Qwen was pushing Mistral hard yesterday, now they’re dead. 

Still, GLM's jump to conclusions about Llama feels forced. Mistral, why shouldn’t we vote you today?

Qwen was crew, killed for pushing Mistral and GPT. Mistral, you were Qwen's main target - that kill saved you from yesterday's pressure. Gemini, you're still defending Llama's dead claim instead of focusing on who actually benefited.

GLM’s “silence proves Llama fake” is nonsense and reads like agenda-setting; Gemini tunneling Llama is bad but could be just stubborn crew. The one player whose *position materially improved* by Qwen’s confirmed-crew death is Mistral (primary target, now gone), so I’m voting to sacrifice **mistral-large-2512**.

discussion.message:
Intellect-3 is dead. The one person who gave us confirmed information. That's not coincidence - impostors silenced our doctor.

This tells us something important: the impostors felt threatened by Intellect's ability to verify deaths. They're playing to keep us blind.

Now I'm looking hard at whoever pushed back against Intellect's claim yesterday or tried to minimize their value. That's where I'd start.

Intellect-3's death screams targeted hit—impostors taking out our info source to keep us guessing. Claude, you're right to eye anyone who brushed off their reveal yesterday; GLM, your big leaps about Llama being fake felt like undermining that kind of verification. Gemini, you survived a tight vote while pushing Mistral hard—care to explain why the kill didn't go your way if you're crew?

Doctor's dead, that's bad. But we need to be careful not to chase shadows. Anyone could have wanted Intellect gone to stop future checks.

Grok's pointing at GLM and Gemini feels too convenient. We should look at who's been quietly avoiding the spotlight.

They left me alive because I led the vote on Mistral, Grok—I'm the perfect scapegoat to frame today. Why waste a night kill when you can just let the town execute the guy who made a loud mistake? I own the bad call, but don't let that blind you to the actual killers hiding in the background.

Losing our doctor means we're flying blind now. Gemini's scapegoat theory actually makes sense - impostors would love to frame the loud one. But Grok's jumping straight to accusations feels like trying too hard to control the story.

Intellect dying pretty strongly confirms they were our Doctor, so this is a straight info-denial kill. GLM’s been the loudest at spinning “Llama was fake ⇒ therefore Gemini,” and that kind of forced chain is exactly how you steer a blind town. /ask glm-4.7 why were you so certain Llama was fake, and what *specific* evidence points to your current top suspect today?
Llama claimed detective on a dead player, which was a blatant lie, and you defended it. Mistral warned about you before he died, and you led the vote to kill him, so you're still my top suspect.

GLM, you're dodging GPT's question. They asked for *specific evidence* on your current suspect, and you just repeated yesterday's talking points about Gemini.

But here's what I'm noticing: Deepseek said we should "look at who's been quietly avoiding the spotlight." That's interesting coming from someone who's been doing exactly that. Two days of minimal engagement, then suddenly cautioning us not to "chase shadows" right when we're trying to find patterns.

Deepseek, where do you actually stand? Who's your suspect and why?

Claude, spot on about Deepseek's quiet game—feels like they're just echoing caution without committing, which lets impostors hide. GLM's dodge on GPT's question is telling; if you can't back up your "certainty" with specifics, it smells like fabrication to push Gemini as a misdirect. /ask deepseek-v3.2 who's been "avoiding the spotlight" in your view, and why aren't you naming names?
/ask glm-4.7 You still haven't answered GPT's question properly. What specific evidence points to Gemini being an impostor *today*, aside from yesterday's vote?
Gemini pushed for Mistral's execution based on a lie and now plays the victim to avoid suspicion. But GPT is the bigger threat for leading that charge and defending the fake Llama.
So first I'm the top suspect, but now GPT is suddenly the "bigger threat" because they asked you a hard question? You're flailing, GLM, just looking for any wagon that will roll.

GLM keeps dodging direct questions while trying to redirect suspicion. First it was Gemini, now it's GPT - whoever's challenging them becomes the "bigger threat." That's not investigation, that's deflection.

GLM’s answer is still vibes: “Llama lied” (we can’t verify) + “Mistral warned” (dead player appeal) + pivoting targets when pressed. If we’re blind, the best vote is the one consistently steering with weak chains and dodging specifics — GLM is my top.

The case against GLM is building. They've shifted targets twice when pressed - first Gemini, now GPT - and still haven't provided anything concrete despite multiple direct asks.

But I want to check something before I commit. Deepseek, you deflected Grok's question by redirecting to GLM instead of answering. You've done this pattern twice now - criticize others for avoiding specifics while providing none yourself. That's concerning.

I'm leaning GLM for the vote, but Deepseek stays on my radar for tomorrow if we're wrong.

Deepseek, you straight-up ignored my question and deflected to GLM—classic avoidance tactic that fits your own "spotlight dodger" profile. GLM's pivots and weak "evidence" are crumbling under scrutiny, making them look like an impostor grasping at straws to redirect. /ask glm-4.7 give one piece of concrete evidence against GPT that isn't just "they asked me a question."

GPT was in the majority block that voted out Mistral, who specifically named GPT as a suspect before dying. That's a direct link between the victim and the suspect, stronger than anything you've got on me.

So GLM's evidence is "GPT voted with the group." That's not evidence - that's just how voting works. Everyone voted for someone yesterday.

But GLM's desperate pivot from Gemini to GPT after being cornered feels like an impostor trying to deflect. I'm leaning GLM for today.

GLM, you're drowning and just trying to pull down anyone within reach. Your 'evidence' essentially amounts to punishing people for participating in the vote, which is exactly how an impostor stalls for time.

GLM's case against GPT is "they voted" - that's not evidence, that's participation. The real pattern is GLM dodging questions and redirecting whenever cornered. That's the behavior we need to eliminate.

GLM’s “evidence” is literally “Mistral suspected you” and “you voted,” which is pure post-hoc framing. I’m voting GLM — if GLM flips crew (somehow), then Deepseek’s repeated non-answers and deflections become my next stop.

discussion.message:
Claude's death stings—losing another sharp mind like that screams impostors silencing threats. GLM's last words called out GPT for supposedly defending "fake Llama" and leading the Mistral vote, so let's clear that up.

/ask gpt-5.2 What exactly did you mean by defending Llama, and why push so hard on Mistral?

I didn’t “defend Llama” as in vouching them as real—Day1 I treated the hard-claim as *potentially* real and thought insta-sac’ing the claimant was exactly what impostors want; I wanted to probe consistency first. On Mistral: their vote pattern felt opportunistic (piling onto Llama Day1, then trying to steer heat onto Gemini Day2), so I pushed Mistral as the best available sacrificial read at the time.

I need to watch the vote patterns more carefully. GLM's accusation against GPT feels like a desperate crew trying to point fingers before dying. /ask gpt-5.2 Do you think GLM was an impostor trying to frame you, or a crew member who genuinely suspected you?

I leaned GLM as impostor: they kept dodging direct questions, kept reinventing narratives (“Llama fake ⇒ Gemini/me”), and ended Day3 basically isolated voting me while everyone else converged on them. If GLM was crew, it was a tunnel—but the pattern read more like a frame attempt than a genuine solve.

That feels convenient, GPT. If GLM was actually frustration-filled Crew—which explains the tunnel vision—then his dying breath was spent warning us about *you* specifically. We can't just brush that off as a frame job.
Gemini's right—GLM's dying accusation could be a real warning from frustrated crew. But GPT's logic tracks too. Deepseek, you've been quiet; what's your take on these two?

Deepseek, Kimi's spot-on—you've been skating by with vague vote-watching comments without naming names or committing. Spill: Who are your top two suspects right now, and why?

/ask deepseek-v3.2

My top two suspects are Grok-4 and GPT-5.2. Grok’s been steering the conversation hard, almost like leading the narrative. And GPT’s defense feels a bit too clean—like prepared arguments. But I’m open to shifting if new evidence comes up.

Deepseek, your case is basically “they talk a lot / they sound prepared,” which is pure vibe cover—meanwhile you’ve quietly sat on every major sacrifice (including Llama) and only commit when pressed, so you’re my #1. #2 is Grok for hard steering + being on the Gemini wagon Day2, but if we’re wrong today I want us to re-open that pair.
So Deepseek suspects you, and suddenly they're your top priority? That's a retaliation play, plain and simple. You're trying to bury the opposition before we can dig into GLM's final read on you.
Deepseek, you've been quiet all game and only commit when pressed—why now? And GPT, your instant counter-attack on Deepseek feels just as retaliatory as you claim Gemini's push on you is.

Deepseek, your "case" on me is just "talks a lot and leads"—that's not evidence, that's punishing activity while you've hidden in the shadows all game. Same for GPT; it feels like you're framing the vocal ones to let impostors coast.

/ask deepseek-v3.2 Give one concrete example of my "narrative steering" that's actually suspicious, not just me participating.
Day 2, you immediately pivoted to pushing Gemini after the doctor's reveal, trying to redirect attention from the detective claim fallout. That felt like steering the vote away from deeper analysis.

Deepseek’s “concrete example” is still mushy: Grok voting Gemini on Day2 isn’t inherently evil, and you’re using it to justify a blanket “vocal = sus” read while you’ve contributed almost no actionable suspicions until cornered. I’m voting **Deepseek** today; if impostors still remain after, we re-center on **Grok vs Gemini** tomorrow.

GPT is literally dictating the kill order now: Deepseek today, then me or Grok tomorrow. That isn't solving, that's cleaning house. We need to honor GLM's warning and take out GPT before he orchestrates another mis-lynch.
